description: The Holy Trinity Cathedral, known in Georgian as Sameba (meaning 'Trinity'), stands as the main cathedral of the Georgian Orthodox Church and serves as the official seat of the Catholicos-Patriarch of All Georgia. Built between 1995 and 2004, this modern architectural marvel rises 87.1 meters from ground to cross-top (with the distinctive golden dome reaching 101 meters), making it the third-tallest Eastern Orthodox cathedral in the world. The cathedral occupies a commanding position atop Elia Hill in the historic Avlabari district, overlooking the left bank of the Mtkvari River and providing sweeping views across Tbilisi. The entire complex covers 3,000 square meters with an interior volume of 137,000 cubic meters, capable of accommodating 15,000 worshippers simultaneously. The construction project was conceived in 1989 to commemorate 1,500 years of Georgian Orthodox Church autocephaly and 2,000 years from Christ's birth, though political upheaval during Georgia's transition from Soviet rule delayed groundbreaking until 1995. Architect Archil Mindiashvili's winning design synthesizes traditional Georgian church architectural styles from various historical periods with subtle Byzantine influences, following the norms of 10th-11th century Georgian and Byzantine architecture. The cathedral was personally requested and supervised by Patriarch Ilia II, who even contributed to the interior artwork by painting several icons including a large image of the Holy Virgin at the entrance. The complex includes nine chapels (four visible above ground, five underground), a free-standing bell tower with nine German-cast bells (the largest weighing 8,000 kg), the Patriarch's residence, a monastery, clerical seminary, theological academy, workshops, and beautifully maintained gardens. Construction utilized natural materials including marble floor tiles, with the foundation containing sacred artifacts from Mount Sinai, the Jordan River, Nazareth, Jerusalem, and various Georgian churches and monasteries, plus soil from holy lands. The site controversially occupies land that included the Khojavank Armenian cemetery, mostly razed by Soviet authorities in the 1930s, though the Armenian Pantheon with burials of prominent community members remains visible up the hill behind Sameba.
highlights: The gilded golden dome topped with a 7.5-meter-tall cross is visible from nearly any point in Tbilisi and required approximately one ton of gold for its completion, creating the cathedral's most iconic visual feature.

Five of the cathedral's nine chapels (dedicated to the Archangels, John the Baptist, Saint Nino, Saint George, Saint Nicholas, the Twelve Apostles, and All Saints) are hidden in an underground compartment spanning 35,550 cubic meters with 13.1-meter height, creating a vast subterranean worship space.

The foundation contains sacred relics including stones from Mount Sinai (where Moses received the Ten Commandments), the Jordan River (site of Christ's baptism), Nazareth, Jerusalem, and soil from various Georgian holy sites, literally building the cathedral upon holy ground.

The cathedral interior measures 56 by 44 meters with 2,380 square meters of worship space, featuring ongoing mural paintings executed by artists led by Amiran Goglidze in traditional Orthodox iconographic style.
All nine bells were cast in Germany and feature both mechanical and electronic operation modes, with the largest bell weighing an impressive 8,000 kilograms and audible across much of Tbilisi.

The Sameba Sewing Shop, located on the southern corner of the church grounds behind the stone chapel, operates as a working atelier where skilled artisans hand-embroider church vestments, ceremonial banners, and flags using luxurious fabrics and gold brocade.

A stone bearing one of the first known inscriptions in modern Georgian stands on the complex grounds alongside a structure housing a sixth-century cross, connecting the modern cathedral to Georgia's ancient Christian heritage.
The complex includes two underground floors beneath the main cathedral, with the second basement level housing a museum and conference hall that extend 40 meters below ground level.

Sameba Square surrounding the cathedral commands exceptional westward-facing views of Tbilisi, making it one of the city's premier sunset viewing locations with the cathedral facade bathed in golden light.
Unexpectedly, the cathedral grounds include a coop near the entrance housing ducks, chickens, and peacocks, adding an unusual pastoral element to this grand religious complex.
tips: Visit during late afternoon or early evening near sunset for the most dramatic lighting on the golden dome and westward city views, especially stunning during winter's blue hour when hazy tones wash the skyline.
Arrive before 9am to experience the peaceful atmosphere without crowds and tour buses, allowing for contemplative exploration of the vast interior and grounds.
Observe the strict dress code: women must cover their hair and shoulders and wear long skirts (or use provided wraps available at entrance), while men and women must avoid shorts to gain entry.
Allocate a full 2 hours to properly explore the main cathedral, underground chapels, bell tower, gardens, sewing workshop, and various monuments scattered across the expansive complex grounds.

Attend Georgian Orthodox liturgy services held at 9:00am Sunday or 4:00pm Saturday to experience authentic worship in this active cathedral, or visit during Orthodox Easter or Christmas for spectacular midnight mass ceremonies.

Visit the Sameba Sewing Shop during operational hours to witness master artisans creating elaborate vestments with hand-embroidery and observe rolls of sumptuous fabrics and gold brocade awaiting transformation.
Combine your cathedral visit with exploration of the charming Avlabari neighborhood and nearby Presidential Palace, both within minutes' walk, for a rewarding half-day excursion.

Access the underground chapels if they're open to visitors, as these five hidden worship spaces occupying vast subterranean volumes offer a completely different architectural and spiritual experience from the main cathedral.
Take advantage of the free admission and grounds access during opening hours (8am-10pm), though consider making a donation to support ongoing maintenance and artistic work.
Explore the Armenian Pantheon located up the hill behind Sameba to understand the site's complex multicultural history and pay respects to prominent members of Tbilisi's historic Armenian community.

Check the interior completion status before visiting if historical artwork is your priority, as mural painting continues in some sections, though the ongoing artistic work itself can be fascinating to witness.
Be prepared for potential encounters with beggars around the cathedral grounds, especially near the main entrance, and decide in advance your approach to these requests.
vibe: Sameba radiates a powerful sense of contemporary spiritual majesty combined with Georgian national pride, standing as a bold architectural statement visible across Tbilisi's skyline with its gleaming golden dome catching sunlight and city lights. The cathedral's relatively recent construction (completed 2004) means it lacks the weathered patina and layered historical atmosphere of ancient Georgian churches, instead offering pristine marble floors, fresh murals, and immaculate grounds that feel more museum-like than time-worn. The sheer scale overwhelms first-time visitors as you approach—the building towers overhead in a way few Orthodox churches do, creating an almost intimidating grandeur before you enter the surprisingly peaceful interior where high ceilings, natural light from the dome, and the scent of incense combine with hushed voices and iconography. The vast worship space can accommodate 15,000 people yet often feels serene and uncrowded outside major religious holidays, allowing contemplative moments despite the steady stream of tourists photographing architectural details. Orthodox faithful move through devotional practices with candles and prayers while visitors navigate the space respectfully, creating a balanced atmosphere between active worship and cultural tourism. The gardens surrounding the cathedral provide unexpected tranquility with well-maintained paths, benches, and surprisingly, the sounds of chickens and peacocks from the coop near the entrance, grounding the monumental architecture with humble pastoral life. Sunset transforms the experience as western light bathes the facade in warm tones while panoramic city views unfold, making the hilltop location feel like a sacred vantage point overlooking Tbilisi's evolution. The controversial history of the site—built atop a destroyed Armenian cemetery—adds an uncomfortable undercurrent for those aware of this background, though the nearby Armenian Pantheon offers some acknowledgment of the complex past. The overall emotional register oscillates between awe at the architectural achievement and modern Georgian Orthodox revival, mixed with slight disappointment for those seeking ancient authenticity, yet the genuine faith practiced within these new walls and the cathedral's symbolic importance to Georgian identity create undeniable spiritual gravity.
expectations: Visitors expect an ancient cathedral with centuries of history and weathered architectural details, assuming all major Orthodox churches in Tbilisi date to medieval or earlier periods.
Many anticipate a fully completed interior with comprehensive religious artwork, murals, and iconography comparable to historic Orthodox churches throughout the region.
Tourists often assume the cathedral's impressive exterior and golden dome will be matched by equally ornate and historically significant interior features and artifacts.
First-time visitors expect the site to be purely about the cathedral itself without understanding the broader complex includes multiple buildings, chapels, workshops, and extensive grounds.
Many travelers assume visiting a religious site in Georgia will be informal regarding dress codes and behavior, not anticipating strictly enforced traditional Orthodox requirements.
reality: Sameba is remarkably new, constructed between 1995-2004, making it barely 20 years old with no ancient history, though it powerfully symbolizes post-Soviet Georgian spiritual and national revival rather than offering medieval authenticity.

The interior mural painting remains ongoing in some sections as artists continue their work under Amiran Goglidze's guidance, meaning visitors encounter both completed masterpieces and works-in-progress, though this active artistic process fascinates many observers.

While undeniably impressive in scale and modern construction quality, the cathedral's newness means it lacks the accumulated sacred atmosphere, artistic layers, and historical artifacts found in Georgia's ancient churches, instead offering pristine marble, fresh paint, and contemporary Orthodox aesthetics.

The Sameba complex functions as an active religious center spanning multiple buildings including nine chapels (five underground), bell tower, Patriarch's residence, monastery, seminary, theological academy, sewing workshop, museum, conference halls, and extensive gardens requiring significant time to explore fully.

Strict traditional Orthodox dress codes are firmly enforced at the entrance—women without head coverings and long skirts will be required to use provided wraps, and anyone in shorts (regardless of gender) will be denied entry, demanding modest advance planning or wardrobe adjustments.
unique_facts: Catholicos Patriarch of Georgia Ilia II personally participated in creating the cathedral's artwork, painting several icons including the prominent large image of the Holy Virgin visible at the entrance, making this a cathedral literally touched by its patron's hand.

During the 1995 foundation laying, ordinary citizens wrote their names and wishes on the stones that were subsequently incorporated into the cathedral's base, embedding thousands of personal prayers within the building's literal foundation.

The architectural competition launched in 1989 received over 100 submissions in the first round but declared no winner initially, eventually selecting Archil Mindiashvili's design after Georgia's turbulent civil unrest period delayed the project six years.

The cathedral's construction was funded primarily through anonymous donations from wealthy businessmen and ordinary citizens rather than state funds, reflecting grassroots support for the spiritual revival project.
The entire structure extends 40 meters underground below the visible cathedral, creating a vertical architectural experience spanning 140+ meters from the deepest basement to the cross-top.
Sand was transported from Jerusalem specifically for use in the cathedral's construction, literally incorporating holy land into the building materials.

In early January 2024, discovery of an icon depicting Saint Matrona of Moscow blessing Stalin sparked theological controversy and public uproar, with theologians describing Stalin's presence on an Orthodox icon as highly unusual.

The site's controversial history includes construction atop Khojavank, the largest and oldest Armenian cemetery in Tbilisi with 300 years of history and some 90,000 graves, mostly destroyed by Soviet authorities in the 1930s and then disturbed again during cathedral construction with reports of scattered bones and gravestones.

The cathedral complex can accommodate 15,000 worshippers simultaneously, making it one of the largest Orthodox cathedrals globally by capacity, capable of holding roughly 0.5% of Tbilisi's entire population.

The consecration ceremony on November 23, 2004 (St. George's Day) included high-ranking representatives from Orthodox Churches worldwide, establishing Sameba as a internationally recognized center of Eastern Orthodox Christianity.
The nine German-cast bells include both mechanical striking systems and electronic operation modes, representing a blend of traditional campanology with modern technology.
The golden dome required approximately one ton of gold to complete its gilding, creating a landmark visible across Tbilisi that literally gleams with precious metal.
surprises: The cathedral's completion date of 2004 shocks many visitors expecting ancient architecture, yet this modern construction timeline actually enhances its significance as a powerful symbol of Georgian Orthodox resurgence after Soviet religious suppression.
Five entire chapels exist in hidden underground chambers that most tourists never discover, missing a vast subterranean worship complex spanning 35,550 cubic meters beneath their feet.

A fully operational sewing workshop on the grounds produces all church vestments and ceremonial items, offering unexpected glimpses into traditional religious textile arts with master artisans working amid luxurious fabrics and gold thread.

Chickens, ducks, and peacocks living in a coop near the entrance create surreal juxtapositions between barnyard sounds and one of Eastern Orthodoxy's grandest cathedrals, grounding monumental architecture with humble agricultural life.

The controversial construction history atop destroyed Armenian burial grounds remains largely unacknowledged within the cathedral complex itself, though the nearby Armenian Pantheon silently testifies to the site's multicultural past.

Interior artwork remains actively in progress two decades after opening, with artists continuing to paint murals under Amiran Goglidze's direction, transforming the cathedral into an ongoing artistic project rather than a completed monument.

The 2024 discovery of an icon showing Stalin receiving blessings from a Russian Orthodox saint created unexpected theological and political controversy, revealing contemporary tensions within Georgian Orthodox artistic traditions.
Despite its massive 15,000-person capacity, the cathedral often feels surprisingly peaceful and uncrowded, allowing intimate spiritual experiences within architecturally overwhelming spaces.
The complex includes unexpected secular facilities like conference halls and museum spaces in the underground levels, functioning as a modern religious campus rather than purely a house of worship.

Sunset viewing from Sameba Square rivals or exceeds many purpose-built viewpoints in Tbilisi, making the cathedral grounds a prime location for evening photography and city panoramas that few guidebooks emphasize.

The strict dress code enforcement surprises many modern travelers unaccustomed to traditional Orthodox requirements, with entrance staff providing wraps and enforcing modesty standards regardless of tourists' expectations or comfort levels.

Stones with citizens' written wishes from 1995 lie embedded in the foundation, meaning every prayer and footstep literally rests upon thousands of Georgians' hopes for their nation's spiritual renewal after Soviet collapse.
